page.title: 11Mark's History
page.content: In old documents{"Mark"}is variously written March (a marsh),Mercon,and Merk (a boundary). In 1348-49,the Black Death swept from Bath and Bristol over most of Somerset and this area did not recover until the wool trade,introduced by the Flemings began to flourish here,bringing prosperity that enabled the moors to be drained and houses built. The{Pack Horse}is thought to have got its name from the wool packed on to horses from here. It was also a Coaching Inn. The Monks of Glastonbury contributed to the upkeep of the{Church}and the villagers had to give grain and wool to the Great Tythe Barn of the Abbot at Glastonbury. {Locksbroad Farm}is said to have been built by the Monks and is certainly very old. Many of the 30 farms in the area are over 100 years old. The {Vicarage}is also quite old.
